Honestly, I agree. First, they should train to just do nothing and let the software do its thing while the engineers test to see what happens with the additional human factor affecting things like weight or stability, along with making sure that they (the people on the lander) are comfortable or at least ok. Then, they should train with a semi-automated system where instead of the whole thing being automatic, they press buttons, with each button having its own smaller algorithm which controls smaller movements as opposed to the entire landing (like turning, going forward, etc). Lastly, they should train for landing it manually should something go wrong with the algorithms. The semi-automated system would be digital (possibly using some kind of tablet, but some people like physical buttons), and the manual system would be analog.

Interesting premise at the end. This is the Tesla idea that requires a hand on the steering wheel while the “computer” drives. I let mine drive on the main portion of the drive but I intervene when changing streets or entering parking lots. The car stops at red lights and stop signs but requires driver approval to resume travel. At traffic signals it always requires approval even if the light is green. It maintains the speed limit and won’t allow self driving at any speed in excess of that which can be done by just adding throttle . It tells the driver at that time that automatic braking is inactive as long as the throttle engaged..
Tesla has done a great job at thinking thru the possibilities that will be encountered in most driving situations. Their Full Self Driving software is, at this time, released as a beta version to only drivers that prove through their actual driving that they can be trusted with more computer control of the driving. Teslas says that even if the beta is offered to a good driver, tha offer may be rescinded at any time if the driver proves less than exemplary in their driving habits.

And about humans doing the landing if they need to...all of SpaceX hardware to date has been designed to work without human interaction, and even the Crew Dragon has very simple controls the astronauts have trained with in a software simulator.
This is not a cold war race, if there's a problem they abort to orbit, period, even if it will take years to try and land again.
Unless NASA mandates it we are not going to see a Gravity Cancellation System under any Apollo style testbed landers (eg BO or Dinetics ones if they find some money for them) for humans to train on Earth, nevermind having one under that behemoth known as StartShip; you simply can't fly a skyscraper manually. NASA has required at least one (probably more) uncrewed landing(s) on the MOON to be performed automatically before Artemis 3 is launched. This is already light years from the type of risks they were willing to take during the Apollo era.
Training on military aircraft style mechanical simulators? Remote piloting of one of these testbeds, maybe with augmented reality? Maybe even land the real thing from the lunar gateway (fingers crossed)? Yes.
But if the testbed is more dangerous than going on the moon (maybe they can make a safer LLTV for some types of landers) or it's impossible to reproduce the same conditions for that vehicle (StarShip, how do you reproduce being on top of a flying skyscraper on Earth?), it's not going to happen.
Flying stuff with a rocket engine in space manually has always been the exception rather than the norm, we should be less romantic more rational about how we approach this discussion.

Likewise, crafts are designed by engineers, not pilots, and engineers can not replicate a pilot.  No matter how advanced or impressive the automation becomes, experience and good judgment of a human, at this time, seems to still be surperior.  That's only my opinion of course.

To answer the question, you need both. Robotically controlled systems with trained backup pilots in case anything happens that needs that human element. Think of an Airbus, they can automatically take off, autopilot, and auto land all by themselves, but obviously we have pilots there to monitor and control the automation to some degree. The same thing applies with the new era of space exploration. Computers can think and react faster than we can, but they can’t always think or react as intelligently or intuitively as we can. We need each other if we plan on going any further than the moon, but we need each other to get even to the moon. Computers and pilots need to learn to work effectively and efficiently together.

24:37. This discussion was already decided decades ago with auto land systems in aircraft. If you permit a passenger aircraft with hundreds of passengers on board, to land by computer control in blind flying/fog conditions, do you want the pilot to be able to override and fly manually? The answer was yes then, and it is yes now. Even if that override is to abort, the decision and monitoring loop is the same. The lunar lander will apply the same logic. There can never be a system where ONLY the automation is qualified to land.

Fun fact: the lunar lander WAS robotic. Excepting the Apollo 11 mission, where the ascent radar wasn’t switched off (and overloading the computer), the navigation computer was capable of completing the landing autonomously. The only intervention required by the pilot was in selecting the landing site.

Experience of automation in aviation up to the day says that autopilot is more precise than humans, and (most importantly) is more reliable. The only reason a human is needed in the cockpit is when things don't go as planned - the automatics is helpful only in "standard" situations which it has an algorithm programmed for. So the weakness of automation is only in the lack of versatility. But for a very specific mission like a lunar landing, which doesn't have as great variety of scenarios as daily aviation, a good coverage can be achieved easily. Therefore having computers at control at all times is the way forward. Training a human to do this job ("just in case") would be a waste of resource. Human skills would be more valuable making high-level decisions (where to land) while leaving the low-level job (how to land) to the machine. So I'd say don't even bother training humans to fly the lander.

The question of allowing humans to still train and have final control over landing or other flight aspects, I believe, has been answered with incidences seen in commercial flying. More and more of commercial planes are designed to have computer controlled functions and some of these, like the A320, have had accidents because human pilots were not allowed to override the computer systems when the computers failed to account for some anomaly they weren't programmed to handle. This led to loss of hundreds of lives that could have been saved if the human pilots could have intervened.

Human spacecraft with few minimum redundancies and a skimpy track record certainly need the ability for humans to overwrite. But I don't think that'll necessarily stay that way forever, especially with future advances in AGI. Today, taxiing and takeoffs in commercial airplanes are still done manually and autolanding capabilities are rarely used, for numerous reasons, probably including that it isn't cheaper to replace a pilot than develop a fully autonomous system that is at least 10x safer than the best pilots. The same will probably be true for space flights, even in a future where they're frequent and inexpensive.

why we wouldn't just have a pilot that will fly the ship the exact way he will fly a vertical takeoff plane on earth, and have a computed algorithm that will translate his commands to fit to whatever planet he is trying to land on?
why would we ever have to teach someone the different mechanics of flying in different places, when we could just come up with one algorithm to just translate his commands to fit whatever.
sure, if you wanna move forward you need more angle on the moon than on earth, but when youre actually flying it on the moon, we could have an algorithm that takes the same joystick input from the pilot as if he was on earth, and then translate it to the actual joystick position needed on the moon, and tilt the right bigger angle instead.
so you don't need to learn two different types of flying, just one universal one.
this solution is more scalable, so it definitely should be the solution we try to find, not manually changing our flying habits just because the area we are flying in happens to slightly change rules.
ultimately you need to have the ship itself pick up all the different elements of the environment that make up the rules, and then apply them to the algorithm to make the pilots controls fit.

Awesome video. Very cool to see how they’re preparing for Artemis. However, the idea for giving a human control override capability is obsolete. You said it yourself. “Neil Armstrong was running an algorithm in his head.” Controlling a vehicle is a very poor use of the human mind. It’s a repetitive task based on measurable factors that can easily be handled by a computer, which can gather far more information, process it much faster, and achieve a much more optimized result, in both control and fault tolerance.

Sensors, computational ability, and system design surpassed human coordination 20 years ago, and it’s only gotten better since then. The extremely limited capabilities of human perception and our highly unreliable processing system would be far more likely to introduce a fatal error than correct for one. This is why pilots who fly “fly-by-wire” aircraft refer to themselves as “a voting member”. They make suggestions. The computer figures out whether or not they’re any good, and tries to accommodate them when making its decision about how to control the aircraft.

You’re also looking at it wrong, as if we’re using a computer to replace human skill. Computers use algorithms developed by hundreds of human engineers through thousands of hours of testing. They don’t replace us, they simply condense combined knowledge into an automated system to offload repetitive tasks. Computers handle the boring stuff so we’re free to do much more interesting, creative things.

I feel like Destin's answer at the end (~24:00) is kind of a cop-out. The comparison is almost phrased as 'would you rather have a flight-competent pilot behind the stick of your vehicle with great software or would you rather have an inexperienced pilot relying on your great software?'.

No one is going to pick the latter. It would be more interesting to have some constraints on the decision. AKA based on time and budget, you can have a pilot trained for 240 hours on a physical system with software that has 1,000 hrs invested in it (development/algorithm training) OR a pilot trained for 240 hours in a digital simulator who will ride on a system with software that's been developed/trained for 10,000 hours.

Don't focus on the numbers but focus on the idea of constraints and trade-off. Imagine you had a hard budget (e.g. $1B) and timeline (e.g. 3 years) for this project. What you pick has a lot more weight and it takes away some of the opportunity to say 'we'll develop both options fully, in parallel!' . This is how projects can get cancelled at NASA after ten years...

Consider how many actual humans have made the journey to the lunar surface with ANY technology. NOW, consider, for a moment, some of the outstanding little things we discovered from those very few journeys made... from cosmic rays "sparkling when your eyes are closed" to the shear numbers of impact craters visible when "up close" even though they weren't so evident from telescopic views here on Earth...

It's ONLY reasonable to keep the redundancy of a human "in the pilot's seat" with over-ride controls available to land the craft manually. Going to the moon, even as a "return trip" is still VERY MUCH pioneering work. It absolutely MUST be treated as such, and that means a minimal redundancy when it comes to controls and tasks and legs of the journey. Anything otherwise would ONLY be "inviting disaster" with a side order of "tempt fate". There are likely a multitude of things we haven't seen that could send the systems into catastrophic distress or shut them down entirely, and there's literally no way to plan for them, because there's no way to predict or anticipate them.

The same should be said for a trip to the Martian Surface... or orbit for the matter. ;o)

The earth-gravity-canceling-thruster will not cancel out gravity because it is a fixed thruster. If you wanted to cancel out gravity you would have to have the thruster change its angle to maintain a perpendicular orientation to the planet rather than the craft, but it would also still need to be centered compared to the craft's mass. Which could be done with a powered double-axis mounting.

Destin,
To answer you question, you need both systems... automatic push button and manual override (and the knowledge to manually fly it).

For anyone that has played Kerbal, Mechjeb is the automatic push button solution for landing anywhere or docking in space.
When things go wrong with Mechjeb, switching to manual and flying by the seat of your pants, is close to heroism.

It is not easy flying by instruments, managing 5 axis and understanding orbital dynamics at the very last few seconds before something catastrophic could happen.
Sure, it is a video game, but it it alternates between joy and terror in a flash.
It teaches the obvious with a simple good lesson: practice makes perfect.

There is no way we are going back to the moon "safely" without 100 % manual override in case of control failures and / or failures of backup control systems.
Redundant control systems are great, having an additional human override on top of it is best.

You are exactly correct on human involvement in landing. I’m a machinist that has used and made automated machines computer assisted machines. The human needs to be involved. In that time I recognized the coyote, I understood what I needed to do to be safe, don’t jerk the wheel and try to avoid. I was able to survive.
Another example: a helicopter pilot told us a story about losing control of his helicopter where he spun around in circles close to the ground after taking off. He had difficulty controlling his machine because he couldn’t get the controls over to the right. For some reason he manage to get the helicopter to fly straight ahead at 80mph to gain control and then he skidded onto the runway to a stop under control. They later found that a very small piece of debris had jammed the controls. All of this took place in seconds.
Point is that the human can recognized events and apply past experience, knowledge and skills at an astonishing speed that a machine will never match.

I reckon they could relatively easily turn these landers into a simulator. They just need a way to send the IMU data to a (somewhat modified) flight simulator and send the inputs from the pilot in the simulator back to the lander in as close to real-time as possible, and cover the lander with cameras to provide the visual reference. The pilot could then practice landing the lander from the safety of the flight simulator, experiencing the same motions it's experiencing just like they did in the Apollo program, and just like pilots practising flying a plane.

Yes, I realise I've vastly oversimplified the concept. They would need to sample the acceleration of each of the IMUs axis' thousands of times a second, and stream that data into the actuators of the flight simulator. And by "stream the data into the actuators", I mean translate that data into motion that feels equivalent, and do so in as close to real-time as possible. Because you obviously can't have a flight simulator that goes up and down by hundreds of metres, just like you can't have an aircraft flight simulator that accelerates to aircraft speeds and continues to move at those speeds. That would just be an aircraft.

Any lander that is designed to carry humans IMO must have the capability for manual control. Period. Unalterable algorithms are fine for a robot/drone lander - but to entrust human lives it needs humans to be able to override since they are the ones *actually there, in real-time*.

The question you ask is very similar to one that has influenced submarine design. 688 class submarines and most of the prior gen submarines were all designed around the idea that every system should have a manual human controlled alternative available. This philosophy has shifted in recent years to one in which humans are being removed from the equation due to the cost and complexity inherent in creating dual control systems. I’m of the opinion that when perceived risk is low we tend to not engineer systems to be as robust, it’s only when a failure occurs that we then shift the focus to providing redundant methods. In other words it’s a graveyard mentality that will only address a risk after its occurred having already caused significant harm or loss of life.

Destin: As a software lad, and a member of the Manual Shift Preservation Society, I can see your argument from both sides. Here's where I think the manual shift loses: In the Apollo era, they landed the LEM manually because they had to: there wasn't enough processing power in the AFC to handle a landing. Now we've got enough processing power to set Perseverance down on Mars via marionette strings and "no break'um egg."
But...if you have a CH9 or CH10 challenge (and as was rightly pointed out, the miracle wasn't that Armstrong put the LEM down without cracking it, but that 6 LEM pilots managed it 6 times, perfectly) then why would you have any software stability moderator at all.
Maybe I'm talking out of my hat, but as a performance driver, I'm doing something simple compared to piloting, even when I'm in the teeth of it. My experience with the SAE J3016_201609 0-5 levels of automation in self-driving cars, is that we either need to be at zero (no system correction for driver error) or five (no driver required.) Automated stability systems trip up a competent pilot the same way they trip up a competent pilot. Yes, as I said, I'm dealing with fewer axis. But when I want to hang the rear end out going around a right corner and take the shear force on the treads, automation steps in (Vehicle Stability Control) and gently applies braking to the rear wheels and front left wheel to take my precisely considered oversteer and adjust the inertial moment so it lines up with the longitude of the car. What might have been a very needful act on my part while on the track means that I just sideswiped another driver at speed because my "system" thinks it knows better.
So either all on, or all off. But lets not get a pilot crossed up when she's at a CH9 event and you have to remember to turn off the stabilizers so you can actually own the controls.

The LLV should be like every other automation or assistance tech we have already, planes and cars may be able to pilot themselves but a human can (for better or worse) take over at any point.
I remember the interview with Neil, they learned a lot by having a pilot actually fly the vehicle.

About the human vs AI landing. Humans make mistakes, I know it sounds a lot cooler that a human has to learn how to pilot a vehicle in another planet and it can only train on Earth but the real question is: Which one is more reliable? Sure an AI can do things wrong but humans makes all kinds of mistakes too. On the ISS, when there's a spacewalk to repair something, there's an entire team looking and monitoring every move and aspect of the mission, the human has had a huge amounts of trainning and there are soo many eyes looking at what's happening that a mistake is unlikely.

On the other hand, we have Perseverence on Mars which, after a lot amount of work and incredibly good engineering, it was able to land without any input from humans. This had to be done due to the huge delays that an input from Earth would have but it shows the amount of potential a well tested machine can do.

A good AI can react faster and without hesitation. Deep learning is also showing us that a good trained AI can predict better than some of our models and they can have better perception of the enviornment. So if the proper tests are done, I think an AI will always outperform a human just because we design them to do so. Does that mean a human doesn't need to know how to pilot the spaceship? I think the more safety features the better. A human understanding what's happening and being able to do it himself/herself to me it's a safety feature so I would train someone for sure, but that wouldn't be my plan A.

I think the best thing to do is have a software assist. The software knows what's supposed to happen, but the human will ultimately make the decision on what is safe and what is not. A software-based system may want to land the lander faster than the human would think is safe because human reaction times are not as fast as the software. That being said, the software is great for stability and control systems where the system must react much faster than a human can to avoid problems.

Moreover, I think training should be done with a drone and simulator system. You have the drone do the actual flying with the anti-gravity assist that will make it react like in 1/6 Earth gravity and have the human in a flight simulator that simulates 1/6 gravity on themselves and provides motion-based feedback of what's going on with the drone. You have the advantage of flying an object that will look and feel as close to the real thing as possible while also minimizing the risk to humans during training.
So what you are saying, re: piloting, is that when it comes to the moon, there is a Human Decision Required.

I think I understand the sentiment of your statement at the end of the main segment of the video. You feel that the drama of human accomplishment of manually landing the craft is what's important here. I don't agree with you, and here's why.

It's the same reason it's not compelling to merely go back to the moon. We've already done it. It would be cool for geeks, but so what? All that's saying is, "We're as cool as we were 60 years ago." It would be the same as if the Apollo astronauts merely flew a 12 second 120 foot flight in a simple Wright Flyer from 60 years prior to them. It wouldn't be cutting edge exploration. Should the pilot be able to override the system and make decisions? Certainly. Might they have to do it on an Artemis flight? Yes. Shoud they train for it? Absolutely. But should our goal be to use the newest technology to do the newest coolest things that science and engineering have developed? I would say yes, or there's no reason to do it. Either do cool lunar stuff or don't do it.

Here's something I disagree with Destin with, and that's the human control element of a lander. I don't think the humans should be "taking control" of the lander if the algrothim doesn't perform, I feel it should be the other way around. Humans should be landing it, with the computer essenitally backing them up should anything go too far. Computer reaction times are far faster than a humans, and with the right software probably more precice. Mostly here I'm thinking of how ABS brakes in cars are developed and used. The driver still drives the car, and can use the breaks to stop, but the ABS manages the breaks for a more effective and controlled stop. If we apply this style of system to the lander then surely the humans can pilot it down, and should anything unsual happen the landing system takes over and re-centers and balances the vehicle. And like the breaks, if the human wants to stop breaking they take the foot off the breaks, if the pilot wants to stop the landing, the hit a thrust acrion and makes another attempt.
This means yes, we need to make a polited test vehicle, and all the learning that comes from not only designing, but interfacing and practing the use of the lander, but also how the human element affects things, like a human reaches for a lever, this very slightly moves the center of balance of the vehicle. Most pilots default account for that, and computers would need to learn how to account for that too. So much to understand about interfacing the human and machine in a foreign environment, that we just can't know until we test.

There were a lot of comments and questions about the EGC (the large earth gravity canceling rocket in the middle that cancelled 5/6 of earth gravity) not being gimballed. There was a trade done on whether to add a gimbal to the EGC. In addition to adding mass and complexity, it would have been very challenging to keep a gimballed EGC pointing through the center of mass of the system. A fixed EGC allowed much better alignment of the EGC with the center of mass of the system. If the thrust didn't go through this point, it would produce a torque around the vehicle. Since the EGC had several pounds of thrust which was much more than the small attitude thrusters, the vehicle could only handle a few centimeters of misalignment. Designing a gimballed EGC to do this would have required not just tilting the EGC to stay vertical but also moving the location of the thrust. This would have been a fun mechanical design but it would have been quite challenging to get right.

With a fixed EGC, this complexity went away. Since we didn't pitch over very far, the EGC still cancelled the difference in earth and lunar gravity very well. (cosine 10 deg is close to 1 for the engineers out there). The main impact of the fixed EGC was that when the vehicle pitched over, the EGC thrust also pushed us laterally (sine of 10 deg is not close to 1!). This effect was not small but we accounted for it when designing the control system. Since the vehicle used the thrust to move sideways by pitching over, we only had to pitch 1/6 of what we would have to do on the moon.

Like many engineering systems, this was a compromise. The simulations of the mighty eagle modeled the fixed EGC and gave us confidence in our entire system. A system designed for the actual moon would be tuned for the actual thrust required on the moon.

I strongly disagree on the "human element" of this.   We need the ability to fly and land cargo - for every kilogram of human we send to the Moon, we'll be sending hundreds of kilograms of "stuff" that humans need there - food, water, air, a habitat, a power source, vehicles, space suits...you name it.   Since humans are fallible, we don't want to risk a human pilot in every one of those flights.  So cargo flight has to be autonomous.   Once you have very reliable autonomous cargo landing - that you've done dozens of times without a problem - then landing a human using the exact same system is the smart thing to do.   It's also cheaper - training astronauts to fly manually is a costly business - we can avoid the need for that.    Automation is also allowing more people to go there.   Suppose you want to send a TV documentary crew to the Moon - you don't want to have to train them to fly a lander.  You want them to push one big red button that says "GO TO THE MOON" and have it "just work".   Sure, it's not very "Buck Rogers" to do that - but it's the rational way to go now we're here in the 21st century.   We have self-driving cars, we have self-flying drones, we have rockets that can send something into orbit then return to Earth and nail a landing onto a barge out at sea.   For an autonomous machine, the moon is EASIER - with less gravity, everything happens more slowly.   With no need to cope with wind or clouds or fog or rain or snow.    Landing on the Moon is a precisely repeatable environment.   For a human, it's harder because our sense of distance - of orientation, etc - is fighting our earth-evolved bodies.  The Apollo astronauts continually had problems with judging distance because the horizon is closer, the lack of atmospheric attenuation of the light made it hard to judge distances too.  The lack of erosion on the surface made everything sharp and hard edged which doesn't look like Earth terrain.   The fractal nature of cratering leaves you without size cues.   We know roughly how big a tree is - we know how big a house or a car is.   We use these cues all the time...but on the Moon, it's not like that.   Human pilots have to fight their natural instincts - autonomous systems do not.

No mention of a gimbal for the EGC thruster to keep it aligned with earth's gravity vector. If attitude changes (i.e. the vehicle tilts to not be parallel with the earth's surface) without the EGC gimballing to point perpendicular to the earth's surface, then the control algorithms will not reflect reality. Gravity compensation thrust would decrease and lateral thrust would increase the further the vehicle "tilted" out of level flight. It would seem that the most complex aspect of the test vehicle would be the EGC gimbal. It either A) had one which Destin and Logan neglected to elaborate on, or B) Didn't have one, invalidating this test vehicle for anything but perfectly level flight operations.

In regards to whether or not a pilot should have the ability to land the lander, regardless of the sophistication of the software on board, I say yes, and let me explain why.
There's a reason we still have pilots on aircraft. they mostly fly themselves now, but we still pay these people to sit at a bank of controls on a flight deck and watch some displays, because we trust human judgement and instinct over machine logic (see the Boeing MAX series crashes, caused by an flight augmenting system). Autopilot systems have been in development for almost a century at this point (starting in WWII), but we still use pilots.
So when asked if a pilot should have final authority over controls on a lunar lander, or if it should lie with a system we can only test in a simulated environment, I say that the pilot should always have the final say. As for whether they need a full training rig? Let's just say that if airlines invest so much in training their pilots in simulators, even with the sophisticated autopilot we have; I would hope that a lunar lander pilot has had experience in a proper simulator.

The gravity reducer does not work in a way that can be used to "train" the software as is here implied.
The "anti gravity" thruster always creates a force in the Z-direction with respect to the vehicle while it should produce thrust perpendicular to the surface of the planet. When this "Mighty Eagle" rotates, for example, it will experience a horizontal force and a reduced vertical force. That would not happen on the moon. So software designed from this model will fail on the moon.

No astronaut actually flew the lunar lander completely. There was a totally manual mode, requested by the astronauts, however it was never used. The Apollo Guidance Computer running P61 flew the lander much like a DJI drone today. Neil Armstrong took over the landing yes, but only into Fly By Wire mode where the sticks told the AGC where you wanted to go and the AGC triggered the appropriate thrusters to go there. Armstrong was essentially supplying the ground recognition for a safe landing area.
So a software based solution today might be totally appropriate.

My biggest question, that I'm sad was not asked, is how the Mighty Eagle handled the thrust vector from the EGC thruster.  It's not gimbaled, so the whole problem of having to pitch further in lower gravity (with less vertical thrust) for equivalent horizontal acceleration is not simulated.  The EGC vector angles with the vehicle and so it is indistinguishable from any other landing thruster.  When Mighty Eagle pitched, it had the full sine component of the EGC thruster also adding to it's translation.  The only time the EGC thruster was actually exactly canceling Earth's gravity would have been when the vehicle was not accelerating horizontally, and that's basically the only time an EGC thruster is needed from a simulation standpoint.  I find it odd that they used an EGC thruster at all if they were not concerned about translation in lower gravity.  Does anyone have any insight into this?  Was the EGC thruster actually gimbaled and they just didn't mention that part?

As someone who writes firmware for a living, and a bunch of it has gone into medical equipment, don't land people on the moon without a human in the loop.

Even with all of the MISRA guidelines, unit testing, hardware in the loop testing, black box testing, fuzzing, white box testing, code reviews, watch dogs, best practices, rad hardened processors, error detecting and correcting memory, redundant sensors, processors, and actuators, firmware is written by humans and it screws up.

When you go into a FMEA meeting where you look at the failure causes and the criticality of the failures, remember that you've got humans as cargo, not just gear. Assume the software will fail, and it does. Now, how do you mitigate that failure? How do you reduce the probability of failure? How do you reduce the level of hazard when it fails?

You can backstop the software with hardware, you can backstop the hardware with software. But you can also backstop the software with human input, and vice versa, you have the software and human augment each other.

Like a modern chess game, humans can't beat computers at chess anymore, the programs are too good. But a human+computer team do beat computers alone. The teaming of humans and computers is better than either humans or computers. When the computer crashes or encounters something that wasn't in the sim, the human can take over.

So, definitely bring back the flying bed frame, because if it hasn't been tested it doesn't work.

Hey Destin, I agree that we should have a trained human pilot, but only as the last resort. If we're looking for redundancy when piloting a lander, it comes down to how many disparate approaches we can apply. I'm assuming they've currently got hardcoded algorithms with some adjustable parameters. That's one option, and the human is another, but I think we should have at least one more in the form of an AI.

What we're seeing is that machine learning is an incredible tool for interpreting a complex set of data and deriving the correct result. Unlike the human, the AI doesn't bring any Earth-gravity preconceptions, and it doesn't need to be painstakingly written. Instead, it just tries all the different approaches to evolve towards the solutions. Take it a step further and develop a GAN where it tries to land safely while an opposing AI tries to develop a landscape that is impossible to land on. Then both AI will become incredibly robust in a short amount of time. The opposing AI could also be helpful for human pilots' training.

I think that would be the perfect plan B if/when the wrote algorithms fail, or if the pilot is unable to perform. It also means we have a highly adaptive tool that is generalized to conditions we wouldn't expect on just the moon. It could apply to many different missions. I can imagine if we're trying to eventually get lots of people to space, needing lots of highly trained pilots is going to become a limiting factor.

I think it would be way cooler and the pilots involved would all say we should land with humans, however, as SpaceX and others are showing, software is quite reliable now when you have good hardware around it, so it’s likely to be safer when you remove an extra set of human error variables. That said, it may be worth it to have a human land it, regardless, just to say we did it... I mean, a human would still be responsible for writing the code and all of that and therefor for landing it, it’s just way cooler to have a human at the sticks, and may be way more meaningful. As long as we get there, get it done, and get it done safely though, it may not matter exactly how we did it in the long run.

That said, obviously there maybe should be a human pilot override if the software goes haywire... rather than just aborting at that point which would likely be the case if the lander is automated. Obviously, there are still software mistakes because humans program them, but you can iron out those things with software automated test flights, but things like Boeing having set their clocks wrong on their docking capsule show that maybe there should in fact be a human override, unless we think aborting once we get to the moon is an acceptable outcome, rather than having another shot if the software glitches out or crashes or has a programming error... which unfortunately I think may be the likely scenario in the unlikely event that we do have a software malfunction on landing phase.

Did the central thruster that cancels earth gravity have some kind of gimballing mechanism to handle the lander's roll/pitch during flight?  And even if it does, wouldn't it no longer be pushing straight through the lander's center of gravity?  It seems to me like cancelling out earth gravity is only possible if you're able to freely move the thrust vector's theta and phi coordinates to always be pointing away from the vehicles center of mass and towards the Earth's center of mass, which itself seems impossible, but if you were to limit the allowed roll/pitch of during flight to a certain range I suppose it could maybe be possible.  Perhaps with a combination of thrusters gimballing would be sufficient because you could cancel out any roll/pitch created by the gimball no longer pointing through the lander's center of mass, but in that case you'd need effectively two whole separate thruster systems - one for earth gravity cancellation and one for the lander simulation.  Is that what is actually the case with the lander here?

I think Destin is confusing the pilot's ability to "take over" to choose a better place to land, with ability to take over to override flight control and stabilization.    No FBW F-16 or F-117 pilot pilot is trained how to fly those aircraft with their flight stabilization systems turned off because they literally wouldn't know which end to point in the wind.      He mentions using drone tech.  Same there, it's almost impossible for a human to control a quadcopter without a fairly smart flight controller between their inputs and its outputs.       It has been done with manned multirotors, but it's akin to juggling, while standing up in a hammock.     Yes, it doesn't have to be all automated (push a button to land), and agree pilot should be able to steer, but that's not "taking over".  That's just piloting a semi-autonomous craft, just as they do with many others.    I think it would not be smart to ignore over 50 years of advancement in flight control systems.

I think the pilot training needs to be different. Think of a human-rated lander as being a fighter plane's fly-by-wire system. The hw/sw running the craft is a criticality-1 item -- if it significantly fails, you're going to have a bad day. You have to trust it. We now have an accumulating body of experience with successful, autonomous robotic landings that our confidence should be growing when human-rated landers come to being. That said, stuff comes up that you didn't anticipate and the squishware in a trained human skull is fantastic at improvising. Given the situational complexities, I think a pilot wouldn't so much be stick-and-rudder like Neil had to be, but more hacker with fingers altering parameters on an input device (move, slow down, drive around the block one time) to correct for the computer's decisions. Obviously, clear communication and understanding between human and craft (possibly A.I.) will be necessary. Not so much a (old-school term) master-slave arrangement but more a partnership. E.g. computer has a solution for a certain landing site but human would prefer one 50 m to the right and updates the solution with computer able to warn of (and/or correct for) some out-of-nominal condition the human didn't see that could endanger the mission (rinse, repeat).

If I remember correctly, Apollo's Guidance Computer had both landing modes you discussed at the end of the video. Program 65 was the automatic landing system that would throttle based only on radar altimeter inputs, and P66 was the semi-manual control loop (like it wouldn't let you do a flip but you still control the stick).
I think P65 was perfectly capable of landing on its own but the astronauts (probably to the chagrin of the programmers) always flipped the computer into P66 before landing for every mission that made it to the surface.

I agree with you that we still need the astronauts to be able to override the lander and have the skills to conduct landings themselves.  Machines break.  Sensors lie.  ...and all sorts of other unexpected things can happen.  My first thought is maybe there are three modes:  1.  Fully auto - the normal mode.  2.  Augmented mode - a fly by wire mode like what Airbus uses where the pilot requests the machine to take action, but the actual action is carried out by the flight computers.  This would be great to make sure the practice on Earth would "feel" the same as the actual moon environment.  (there is no way to perfectly simulate that environment on Earth even with a EGT or equivalent).  It could also impose soft limits (like bank and pitch limits) just like the Airbus uses.  3.  A fully manual mode in case of a compete failure of the flight control computers.  This would be a 'last option', but an important one if those astronauts have a VERY bad day.  Again, you can do this in fly by wire aircraft where it is called "direct law".  That may never be used in reality, but a successful mission always means planning for the unlikely and still having options for those corner cases.

I figure if you asked these pilots from decades ago if they would rather a computer be in charge of landing, they might say no.

If you posited "what if computers were 100 times more capable" they might say no. "What if computers were 100,000 times more capable and we spent a few decades developing the software skills to model and control flight and avoidance".... I bet they'd start to think and start asking how reliable and high resolution the sensors are because there's a tipping point where we can't trust ourselves and our abysmal reaction times to do the best thing quick enough.

I think there's a line where human control is not a great idea. That said we are fantastic pattern recognizers and creative beasts. I'd love to see more software taking suggestions and overrides from humans.

One example in my field is: when programming C++ a compiler makes a lot of decisions for you about what's best for your program based on some very high level swithches you set like "I prefer fast code over small code"; however you can always hint to a compiler how you want a specific function to be built. Note: "you can hint" not "you can tell". You as a human can't actually control some things but you can tell a compiler what you think about a problem and it will bias towards that solution. [other code nerds: I'm talking about inline and force inline, which still isn't truly forcing]

I'm a fan of this kind of human "control", having humans suggesting actions, not performing them. I'd love to hear anyone else's thoughts on that especially from other fields.

I know this is not the right place to say this but I think I have figured out a way to find ONE WAY SPEED OF LIGHT, please let me know if I'm missing something or making some wrong assumptions.

Let's say we have 2 stationary points A and B in a controlled environment and we know the distance between them.

Now let's put the clock which is already measuring time at point B and a source of light and sound at point A which produce light and sound exactly at same time.

Knowing the mechanism of propagation of sound, we know it travels uniformly in all directions if we have uniform atmosphere (that is why controlled environment for experiment) i.e. we can for sure find the exact speed of sound in that controlled environment

So now someone needs to turn the source on and we record at what time the light reaches the clock and also the time at which the sound reaches the clock.

Now using the speed of sound we can find out exactly at what time the sources were turned on (as we know the distance and speed already)
Since we already know at what time the light reached point B we can easily find how much time it took for light to reach point B from point A.

Now we simply take the distance and divide it by the time it took for light to reach point B from point A and we have the exact one way speed of light.

If this don't work then make a space jet capable of super fast speeds and attach a light source on it and do the same experiment as stated above but swap sound with space jet which starts from rest and is moving towards the observer with a fixed acceleration and make it flash a light towards the observer at the start right when it starts to accelerate

No rocket has ever been into the supposed region of space, nor the moon, mars etcetera since it is contrary to the laws of physics for rockets or thrusters to work in a vacuum. They can only work in the atmosphere of our plane Earth.

Correctly stated, Newton's third law is: For every action their is an equal and opposite reaction. In other words, every force involves the interaction of two separate objects. When one object exerts a force on a second object, the second object also exerts a force on the first object. The two forces are equal in strength and oriented in opposite directions. Therefore, a single mass object cannot move itself. It must have a separate force to interact with.

This being the case, there can be no disputing that nothing on Earth, whether it be biological or mechanical, can defy the physical laws of Earth. These laws assert that every living thing and every man made vehicle on our plane of existence must have the inherent ability to push away from a separate resistant force in order to be able to travel in a given direction. So without separate resistant forces, (force pairs), there can be no thrust and thus no movement.

And, that also applies to rockets, which are single mass objects.

Consider these facts: There are two forces required for a rocket to fly in Earth's atmosphere. Thrust and downward force.

The thrust: comes from the burning of fuel at the bottom end of the rocket where hot gas molecules are forced from the combustion chamber down through the jet nozzles in an unbroken pressurized stream.

The downward force: comes from the ambient external mass of air pressure that completely and constantly presses against the exterior of the rocket and also infiltrates and floods the interior space of the jet nozzles. And it is the friction from this external mass of air pressure that affords the rockets thrust the resistance with which to push away from.

So the force pair is the thrust column and the pressure of air. The thrust constantly pushes away from the resistance of air pressure and the air pressure constantly pushes against the thrust with equal force.

Without this positive air pressure providing a constant resistant force for the thrust to push away from, a rocket could not fly. In fact, without air pressure, nothing on Earth could fly.

In 'space' there is no atmospheric pressure which naturally means there is zero pressure on the rocket and therefore absolutely zero resistance.

The vacuum of what we are told 'space' is, is the complete opposite to the atmosphere of Earth. The heavens as we currently understand them, are completely void. Therefore, as soon as the nozzle is opened to release the gases, the combustion chamber becomes part of the infinite vacuum of 'space'.

This means that when the rocket jets are open, there is no barrier or resistance to prevent the high pressure gases inside the chamber from flowing out into the low pressure vacuum of 'space'. It would be like taking a bottle of air into space. The air inside the bottle would be pressurized and so, when you remove the cap, the high pressure air would naturally flow out into the region of low pressure, (vacuum), to meet equilibrium and disappear into the farthest reaches of 'space'.

Consequently, with no resistant force to stop them, the gases expelled from the open combustion chamber through the jets would immediately disperse into the endless expanse of 'outer space', traveling at a constant speed, never slowing down or colliding with any outside elements, or indeed with each other, the gases would forever move away from the combustion chamber. They would thus be incapable of returning a positive force to the rocket to propel it in any direction.

So, essentially, without the required resistance of positive air pressure to push away from, a rocket could expel its hot gas molecules into 'space' for eternity and not move an inch...

Finally after almost 60 years of alleged space travel, no one on this plane of existence has ever seen a rocket enter 'space' or return from 'space'. No one has seen a rockets thrust working in space or moving a rocket in space, (except for: Hollywood movies, TV series, video games etc.) Every launch is sent up at a non vertical trajectory and arches over the ocean to disappear out of sight where it then crashes into the ocean meeting its predestined conclusion.

There should be an inordinate amount of proof for what was discussed and so it should be incredibly easy to prove. But of course, it isn't easy at all because there is nothing to base these government agencies claims on. Which is why, after almost six decades, believers of the official mainstream narrative are still desperately trying to prove to a rapidly increasing number of doubters that rockets work in space by constantly quoting Newtons 1st, 2nd, and 3rd laws, conservation of momentum, using model rockets in small vacuum chambers or by presenting the usual hypothetical scenarios of guns/bullets, skateboard/bowling ball, etcetera. But these mainstream science pushers can never ever provide independent, fully detailed, verifiable, irrefutable and observable scientific evidence that clearly and unquestionably prove that rockets work in space. And why...? Because, ROCKETS CANNOT WORK IN 'SPACE'.

Regarding your final question, it's going to be a matter of our confidence in the software, which after a lot of rigorous testing might be very high indeed. Armstrong's experience with Apollo 11 (when he had to override the mission plan at the last moment to avoid obstructions on the landing site) suggests we need pilots to be able to make these kinds of decisions. But in this video you showed a test of robotic obstruction avoidance.

Spacecraft re-entry has always seemed to me to be a pretty harrowing aspect of any mission, because of the precision of angle of approach required to pull it off; and yet (for example) we have had hundreds of Soyuz and other re-entries over the decades that I am pretty sure were accomplished without any input from the astronauts on-board. If by the time we are putting people back on the moon we have automated systems that are as reliable as the methods we use to bring astronauts home through Earth atmosphere, we won't need any on-board piloting skills at all. It's not 1969 anymore.

Interesting to note about your point at the end regarding astronauts requiring stick time.  That scenario of untrustworthy software played out during Apollo 11. In terms of how to land, I'm a big proponent of software-based landing. The algorithms we've designed since ~2016 till now in the field of reinforcement learning have shown an incredible aptitude at control tasks, way beyond the skill of humans. By writing solid simulation software and training these algorithms within a virtual environment, they can be exposed to many more (risky) situations than a human ever could; at least safely. This can make a landing vehicle piloted by software vastly safer than one piloted by humans.
That said, like with any system that has the potential to risk human life, it is incredibly important that this software has appropriate sanity checks and bounds within which it is allowed to operate; and in the case of a descent vehicle, there should always be a way to override the system, and pilots need to be trained for this.

A fun tangent: Not all computer operated safety systems should be over-rideable by humans. A glaring example of this exists in the Dutch delta works where storm barriers will close upon a signal of bad weather, and once that signal is passed, the construction (somewhat like a dam) will close. There exists no software or human override. It is designed to be closed by physics alone so that the emotional urge to safe that last boat of people doesn't inadvertently kill thousands.

The things you are talking about are control systems, and they have made gigantic leaps since the 60s and 70s. Not just that, also of critical importance to control systems (whether that control system is in software, hardware or a person) are the sensors, and sensors have made gigantic strides as well.
I am of the opinion though, that computers can more reliably, accurately, precisely and (maybe most important) efficiently guide these processes and get the landing part done.

If you want to know more about it, there's a fellow youtuber 'brain douglas' who has some absolutely amazing videos on it.

Then whatever test subject is in the chamber will experience the lower g during acceleration. The added benefit is you can test higher G planets as well by accelerating upwards. I would point out that Apollo actually used software-controlled landers because the LM's flight and landing systems were entirely automated with the astronauts only needing to input the correct program number to run. Armstong overrode the auto-landing sequence to run the manual landing sequence when he thought that the flight computer was going to take them into a boulder field, and then on every subsequent flight the Commander also took manual control for the landings even though they technically didn't have to do so.

edit: Just on double-checking, one change to the above. The AGC actually changed through the automated landing programs P63, P64, and P65 itself at predetermined points in the landing. The crew was able to bring up P66 (Rate of Descent) and P67 (Manual Guidance) themselves. P67 was the program that was used for manually landing the LM.

I disagree with the in person flight situation. It should be overridable but with the control loop style software and rocket tech that work today, we could send a full unmanned journey to the moon full on software. they went to the ISS on full software. Mars rover lander was full software as radio delay.

You can train software in ways you cannot train a human. Landing on an object so small in comparison, must mean it looks different to the observer in the seat... iow...  the human. The human may be stuck with old "Earth thinking or software" and want to lean too far forward, trying to recreate what they've seen before but on a bigger rock. The software can be made to not know Earth exists.

Seems to me the way space travel is going and where it is now, we are already completely dependent on computer algorithms doing things that are way too delicate or complex for humans to do anyway. So enhancing built in redundancy and reliability and understanding how the algorithms work may dominate our resources of time and knowledge retention.  I'll admit though, I think there will always be a nostalgic romanticism for manual flight control.

My question is whether it‘s actually possible for a human to fly the lander. While National Teams and Dynatics landers are designed to be steerable by a human it would seem unlikely that Starship could actually be controlled by a person.

Imo the best solution is to use a computer trainer pilot to train the astronauts to fly the vehicle so that if the real vehicle has a computer failure the astronauts will be able to take over and land successfully. And I think electric motor powered training vehicle is a very good solution due to the increased flight duration (especially if you connect it with a cable to the ground) and very agile controls that can easily simulate different types of rocket engines. You could even go as far as simulating lunar gravity entirely trough software by having EDFs pointed in all directions. This will make testing much safer than the way they did it back in the day.

Simulations! I really don’t think astronauts/test pilots should really be in that kind of vehicle in the modern age. Everything about SLS and the new moon landing is SAFETY! There is likely a two flank idea for landing. Software as a plan, astronaut and 100s of hours in a simulator as the backup.

Watching that SpaceX launch and docking last year was extremely exciting. But that was all automation. Short of the testing conducted before approach, those two were really just surviving the amazingness of launching into space and watching a bunch of stats on monitors.

It’s great to appreciate the old-school while remembering those Apollo astronauts were literally defying death on nearly every journey. The last shuttle catastrophe destroyed the laypersons perception of space travel. Computers and super smart engineers have made it safer for everyone (so far!).
